content: on the hunt for the missing children you find yourself in the deep dark forest a
small clearing reveals a tiny stone hut in utter disrepair cobwebs and moss
covered this old structure but what really grabs your attention are the
skulls decorating its exterior and the sudden cackling laughter that comes from
within hey guys welcome back to black magic crafts this is officially the
first Friday build video of 2019 and it's a really damn good one if I do say
so myself I wanted to add a hags Hut to my collection and it ended up being a
really fun project with a ton of cool details and embellishments this build is
almost entirely made out of foam but there are some extra little things I
used for details and I'm gonna be combining a ton of different methods
that I've shown previously in other videos but I'm also gonna be sharing
with you guys some techniques that I've never shown before this is a hefty build
there's a lot to cover so I'm gonna stop talking and start building the material
of choice for this build is XPS insulation foam if you don't know what
that is check out my video explaining it I'll put a link on the screen and in the
video description below using my procs on hot wire cutter and my
circle cutting jig from shifting lance comm I cut two circles out of one and a
half inch thick foam the radius of the circle was just eyeballed to what I
thought would be appropriate for a small Hut for the roof I cut two more circles
but this time I set my wire at a steep angle to create two cone-shaped pieces i
hot glued the two cone pieces together flush on one side I was then able to run
them through as a single piece again on the same setup to create one uniform
cone shape I thought that three inches was too tall for the Hutt walls so after
gluing the two circles together I ripped them down to a more appropriate height
again this was just eyeballed to what I thought looked good I try not to get too
hung up on measurements and instead just keep a mini close by to gauge size I
wanted the Hutt to look like it was
constructed by random sized field stones rather than uniform bricks so I had to
figure out a way to cut a bunch of random shaped and sized stones out of
foam I accomplished this by cutting square strips of foam then I started
randomly cutting off all the edges free hand on the proc songs hot wire I tried
to move the strips around a lot to get a ton of variety and make sure not to
leave any flat sides if you're wondering why I switched from pink to blue foam
here the only real reason is that I thought later in the video would be
easier for you guys to see the contrast between the blue stones and the pink
base I was then able to slice these randomly shaped rods into thin pieces to
create a variety of different rocks I repeated the same process but with
smaller strips to ensure I got a good variety of sizes once I had all my foam
stones cut I used my coffee hand technique to tumble them I just placed
the foam pieces in the cab with some real stones and shaped them around for
about 30 seconds this rounds all the edges and adds some
texture to the foam pieces before gluing the stones to the base
shape I wanted to establish my door so that a stone framework could be placed
around it I used this template from shifting lands
to draw a nice arched door on some medium weight chipboard after cutting
out the chipboard I made some strips of fake plank by slicing thin strips of
foam and adding a wood grain with a wire brush I could then glue these planks
onto the chipboard cut off the excess and have a great-looking wooden door if
I was to place the door directly on the cylinder of foam it wouldn't quite look
right with that flat piece on the curve so I traced out the shape and cut away
some excess foam this allowed me to recess the door into the piece for a
more realistic look when doing the stone facade I started with the door frame and
the bottom course of stones I did these using hot glue so that they would
instantly stick in place and would not move around when doing the following
rows this essentially creates a hard border for me to work off of for the
remainder of the stones I prefer to use tacky glue as it gives me some more
working time to shift things around and it's a lot less annoying to work with
then hot glue which creates a lot of wisps I just worked my way up and around
the piece and thankfully had cut pretty much exactly enough foam stones to
complete it on the top row I let the foam overhang until the glue dried this
way I could later just cut off the excess with a sharp blade
I wanted the roof to have a really exaggerated and fairytale looking twist
to it this would be very difficult to do with foam so I created the remainder of
the bent peak using twisted up paper the paper could easily be bent into the
shape I wanted to make it more secure I wrapped it very tightly with masking
tape and continued to compress and bend it into shape for the shingles I cut
very thin strips of foam these strips could then have a woodgrain added to
them with a wire brush after adding the wood grain I split the strip's into
using an exacto knife I intentionally did this freehand so that I would get
variation in the widths so that the shingles looked more like handmade
wooden shingles then I cut the strips to shingle length of about 3/4 of an inch
when doing this you have to decide how much shingle you want showing on the
final piece then cut these about 50% longer than that so you can overlap them
I intentionally cut these at different angles so that there would be a lot of
visual interest on the roof once completed before applying the shingles I
covered my masking tape on the base structure with some hot glue I just
wanted to make sure that there was no chance of it peeling off I also glued on
a scrap piece of foam to the bottom so that I could use that as a handle
wobbling the shingles and later while painting actually laying the shingles
was by far the longest and most arduous task of the build I used hot glue here
instead of tacky glue despite it being more annoying to work with and creating
lots of wisps it's simply too finicky working on small round pieces with tiny
shingles to use any sort of PVA or tacky glue when doing this you want to try and
have the shingles and at different lengths and when you're doing your
courses make sure you properly overlap the seams offsetting your rows by half a
shingle width things start to get pretty tricky the
higher up you go but it's one of those things that you just gotta get through
on a build a point where the thickness of the foam was getting to be too much I
actually used the hot glue nozzle to melt and flatten the foam a bit for
the very top I cut one thin strip of foam that I could wrap around to create
a cone I then split this after it was glued in place to try and make it appear
as though it was actually separate pieces moving back to the base it was
time to do something about the gaps for this I took some drywall joint compound
and mixed in a bit of water down PVA glue I could then coat the piece and
fill the gaps using a mix of a wet paintbrush my fingers and a paper towel
I removed as much excess as possible from the surface of the stones you're
not careful here you can end up putting on too much mortar making it too heavy
that will completely obscure all the definition between these separate stones
you don't want that after the joint compound was dry I could
move on to the Mod Podge step this is a critical step on the roof which is made
up of a ton of little pieces of fragile foam it takes some time to get it in
every nook and cranny on the shingles but using a wet brush helps with that
the combination of joint compound and Mod Podge on the base makes for an
incredibly strong bit of styrofoam I thought this thing needed a chimney so I
grabbed a bit of wood dowel and cut a little length I drilled a hole right
into the roof so I could secure the dowel in place for the top of the
chimney I cut a circle out of paper and created
a cone that I glued on top then I attached the chimney to the roof
intentionally making it a bit crooked to add a bit of that fairytale look to the
piece giving the paper a coat of Mod Podge made it more than strong enough to
paint the stonework I started by painting everything out in a light tan
this would be my base coat for my mortar I intentionally went with a very light
color here as my black washes later would end up turning it quite dark for
the stones I wanted there to be a lot of different colors going on so I painted
the stones out in six different shades of grey tan and kind of Orange II earth
tones this takes a lot longer but adds a great bit of subtle detail to the
finished piece this should absolutely look really
comical and ridiculous at this point because once the wash is applied it'll
really subdue all those colors and blend them together i dry brushed all of the
stones using the same off-white color this picks up a lot of the texture and
edge details and helps unify all of the various colors for the roof I wanted it
to look like a really aged cedar if you saw my gallows video you'll recognize
this method of painting would I use a golden brown that is really watered down
to paint directly on the black base coat once dried this creates a really great
effect that ends up fairly dark brown but with some yellow undertones the door
was painted using the same golden brown but it had a tan undertone and you can
really see the difference that makes I actually decided to repaint the door
black so I could create a matching wood tone on it what really makes the would
look like weathered cedar is an aggressive dry brushing of light gray or
tan this is another time when you want the effect to look really over-the-top
since the wash will severely reduce the vibrance of the dry brushing I painted
out the chimney using a metallic black and decided to also do the little peak
on the top of the roof as it really wasn't looking like wood shingles like I
intended and I thought it would be more believable as a metal cap I also added a
doorknob using my favorite jewelry jumpers that I got at Michaels these are
so perfect for miniature doors if you can get your hands on them the chimney
and roof cap got a dry brushing of gunmetal gray than a quick rust effect
to make them look old and decrepit finally it was time for the wash
I used my homemade black wash recipe I'll put a link to that video in the
info cards and the video description below in case you want to make
our own and I highly suggest you do
you can see just how much the wash brings all the colors of stone and
mortar together and why you need so much contrast in the initial painting for it
to show through later if you find that the wash looks too excessive or dirty on
the flat surfaces of a piece you can use a wet q-tip and wipe away some of that
black wash you have to do this before the wash is 100% dry and you got to be
really careful so you don't accidentally wipe away any of your paint underneath I
also went back all over the stones with a very gentle dry brushing of tan to
bring back some more of those edge details that the wash removed I could
finally attach the roof to the base which I had been dying to do this whole
time but resisted as it was so much easier to work with separately this is a
good example of why I rarely use a large hot glue gun I thought it would be good
to use one to attach the two big pieces of foam together but that amount of
high-temperature hot glue just melts the foam and it's just too much I turned
back to my trusty little gun and it got the job done
right I wanted this thing to look really creepy which meant it needed some
cobwebs technique I discovered and showed in the early days of the channel
is using dryer sheets as cobwebs you have to use the ones that have already
gone through the dryer you know the ones that are going in the garbage anyway
you can rip them up and pull them apart to create great looking webs I glued
them in place using some tacky glue the bit tricky but using a toothpick and
some patience you can get the web sitting nicely on all sorts of different
surfaces
after doing the web's I knew I had to keep going with little embellishments so

I found this owl which I think will be really neat to sit on top it was perched

I found these candles but they weren't sitting on anything so I saved part of

at this point the piece could easily be called done but it decided to take it
